pred:
Scott Sears, a lieutenant in the First Battalion Royal Gurkha Rifles and the brother-in-law of tennis star Andy Murray, has achieved a remarkable feat by becoming the youngest person to reach the South Pole solo and unsupported. At the age of 27, Sears completed a 702-mile trek through harsh Antarctic conditions, including 150mph winds and temperatures as low as -50 degrees Celsius.

The journey, which took 38 days, was filled with challenges such as navigating crevasses, some of which were riddled with danger due to the risk of falling into them. Sears, who is from east London, had to adapt by using skis to cross the ice instead of being roped to a teammate.

The most dangerous part of the journey was the initial section from Hercules Inlet where sea ice meets land. Sears experienced a particularly challenging day on Christmas Eve, just 38km (24 miles) from his destination, where he hit a wall and struggled to continue. However, he managed to push through with some food, music, and motivation, eventually reaching the South Pole on Christmas Day.

Sears' journey ended in a significant personal achievement, but also a significant contribution to the Gurkha Welfare Trust. He raised over £33,500 for the organization, which will be used to rebuild schools in Gorkha, Nepal, that were destroyed in the 2015 earthquake.

Judy Murray, Andy's mother, congratulated Sears on his achievement, while Sears himself expressed his excitement and relief at having completed the journey. He is looking forward to some well-deserved rest, including a shower and food, after spending nearly six weeks alone in a tent.

The Guinness Book of Records is yet to confirm whether Sears' feat will make it into the record books, but his accomplishment is undoubtedly a testament to his resilience, determination, and physical endurance.
answers: While many people were unwrapping gifts on Christmas Day, the brother-in-law of tennis star Andy Murray was wrapping up a 700-mile, 38-day journey through brutally cold temps and blistering winds—and, he hopes, setting a world record. Scott Sears, 27, reached the South Pole on Monday, and he says he's the youngest person ever to do so solo, though Guinness has yet to offer its final seal of approval, the BBC notes. "MERRY CHRISTMAS FROM THE SOUTH POLE! Absolutely chuffed to pieces," he wrote on his blog, where he documented his unassisted adventure, which included temperatures of minus 58 degrees and wind gusts of up to 150mph. Sears said he was so tired when he finally took a rest after his trek that he fell asleep "within about 2 minutes of my head hitting the mat." Sears, whose sister, Kim, is married to the tennis star, describes a grueling expedition with icy, crevasse-marred terrain and an isolation made worse when the "iPod poltergeist" would occasionally strike, causing his music player to stop working. He says he "truly hit a wall" on Christmas Eve, where "everything was just saying 'no more, not one more step.'" But he devoured some dried meat, juice, and chocolate and pushed through, even hanging up his stinky socks as "makeshift stockings" for Santa that night. Sears' message from Andy Murray's mom once he arrived at his destination: "Well done Scott Sears." If Guinness confirms Sears' feat, he'll be three years younger than the previous record-holder, per the Telegraph. (Prince Harry drank champagne out of a prosthetic leg when he arrived at the South Pole.)

pred:
Michael Elliot, a 40-year-old man convicted of four murders in 1993 and serving five life sentences, escaped from the Ionia Correctional Facility in Michigan on Sunday. After his escape, he was on the run for approximately 24 hours, leading authorities on a manhunt that spanned across states. On Monday evening, Elliot was captured in Kankakee Township, LaPorte County, Indiana, following a short chase and subsequent arrest by local law enforcement.

During the chase, Elliot allegedly stole four vehicles, including a black 2002 Chevrolet Monte Carlo that was stolen from the LaPorte area. He was arraigned in Indiana on auto theft charges. The sheriff's department in LaPorte County had been searching for the stolen vehicle, as its engine was left running to warm up when it was taken.

Deputy Jeffrey Wright of the LaPorte County Sheriff's Department was the first to spot the stolen vehicle and attempted a traffic stop. However, Elliot did not pull over and instead led deputies on a chase. Stop Sticks were deployed, causing Elliot to lose control of the vehicle and crash into a snowbank. He then attempted to escape on foot but was apprehended by Deputies Wright and Slawek Czupryna.

Elliot was taken into custody without incident and is being held without bond on felony car theft and resisting charges. He appeared calm and emotionless during the arrest and confirmed his identity when asked. Michigan Governor Rick Snyder thanked the law enforcement agencies involved in the search and capture of Elliot, praising their diligence and professionalism.

Authorities are still investigating the circumstances surrounding Elliot's escape from the Ionia Correctional Facility. He was last seen wearing a white tennis shoe, white t-shirt, black pants, and a white beanie cap. Elliot is described as a white male, 5'8, 165 pounds, with brown hair and eyes. He should be considered armed and dangerous, and anyone who comes into contact with him is advised to contact law enforcement immediately.
answers: A convicted killer who escaped from a Michigan prison yesterday and carjacked a woman has been arrested after a car chase in rural LaPorte Country, Indiana, WNDU reports. Michael David Elliot, 40, allegedly stole a woman's red jeep and abandoned it in the small town of Shipshewana, Indiana, this afternoon. A woman spotted the car and called police, who said the vehicle had been seen in the area as early as 5:30am. Knowing Elliot "can go a lot of places in seven hours," police went door-to-door and had schools locked down before releasing students under a heavy police presence. Then a call about a stolen vehicle came in to the LaPorte County Sheriff's Office, and a deputy saw the vehicle and attempted a traffic stop, WOOD-TV reports. But the driver kept going and led authorities on a 5-minute chase. Stop sticks disabled his tires in Kankakee Township; Elliot jumped out and tried to run but was arrested and booked. He was serving five life sentences for the murders of four people when he broke out of the Ionia Correctional Facility yesterday by slipping through a gap in the fencing system.

pred:
On Friday night in Denver, a high-speed pursuit of a stolen tractor occurred through central Denver, ending in Lower Downtown. The tractor, which was initially stolen from a Denver Water facility at 1600 West 12th Avenue in the Lincoln Park neighborhood, was being pulled by a tractor with an attachment. The chase began near City Park and resulted in several incidents, including the tractor driving on busy city streets, sidewalks, and even crossing Park Avenue.

The pursuit ended near 15th and Market Streets in LoDo, where a police cruiser rammed the tractor, causing it to stop. Two Denver Police Department officers were injured during the chase and were taken to a local hospital. Both officers were treated and released by Saturday morning. Witnesses reported that the tractor driver was apprehended and placed in an ambulance, and no gunfire was used by the police.

The tractor driver's identity has not been released as the investigation is ongoing. Videos of the pursuit show the tractor swerving through the city, striking several cars and buildings. The Denver Police Department is working with Denver Water on the investigation, and more information will be released as it becomes available.

In a separate report, it was mentioned that two police officers were injured during the pursuit and were being treated at a local hospital. The tractor, which was pulling some kind of farm equipment, struck several cars and buildings as it careened through the streets. More than a dozen police cars and a helicopter were involved in the pursuit, and it ended only when a police cruiser rammed the tractor.

Overall, the incidents resulted in property damage, injuries to two police officers, and the apprehension of the tractor driver. The investigation is ongoing, and further updates will be provided as more information becomes available.
answers: Imagine looking outside and seeing over a dozen cop cars chasing ... a tractor. That was the scene in Denver last night when a stolen tractor towing an attachment smashed into cars and buildings as it plowed through downtown, the Huffington Post reports. Addie Hooper, 20, was visiting from Texas with family when she looked out a restaurant window onto Market Street and saw a police SUV crash into the tractor: "We were just like, 'Woah, that's crazy!" Hooper tells the Denver Post. Police vehicles rushed the scene and officers jumped out with guns drawn. "We thought they were going to shoot him," she adds. Instead, officers Tased the driver and made sure he was carted off by ambulance. Two officers sustained non-life-threatening injuries, and no reports have emerged of injured pedestrians. "It could've definitely been a lot worse," a witness tells KDVR. No more details have emerged, but police say the slow-speed chase began around City Park and concluded downtown, where officers rammed the tractor to protect pedestrians. Among Twitter videos, this one seems to capture it best. (Read about the easiest suspect chase ever.)

pred:
In the past few days, tensions between Israelis and Palestinians have escalated significantly, following a series of violent incidents. On Wednesday, a Palestinian teenager, Mohammed Abu Khdeir, was abducted and killed in Jerusalem, allegedly in retaliation for the deaths of three Jewish Israeli teens who were buried hours earlier. The crime was met with strong condemnation from the Obama Administration and European officials, and threatens to further escalate the conflict. The abduction followed a night of mayhem by Jewish extremists, who assaulted Arab Israelis in Jerusalem.

The body of Mohammed Abu Khdeir was found charred in a forest on the outskirts of the city, and his father identified the culprits from a surveillance camera recording. The Israeli police have launched a priority investigation and vowed to punish the perpetrators severely. Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has urged both sides to avoid taking the law into their own hands.

Meanwhile, Israel has also reinforced its forces on the border with Gaza, following air strikes that injured 10 Palestinians early on Thursday. The Israeli military claims these attacks were in response to mortar and rocket fire from Palestinian militants in Gaza. Two homes in the southern Israeli border town of Sderot were damaged overnight, but there were no reports of injuries.

The funeral of Mohammed Abu Khdeir was delayed so that a post-mortem examination could be completed. The examination, being conducted by Palestinian and Israeli doctors, is taking longer than expected due to the extent of the burns on the body. The father of the victim was reportedly held by police for eight hours and put under pressure to say the killing was not in retaliation for the deaths of the Israeli youths.

The Palestinian leadership has accused Jewish settlers of the killing, and Palestinian President Mahmoud Abbas has threatened to drag Israel before U.N. courts. The distance between the two sides appears to be growing with each incident, and there are fears that the funeral, when it does take place, will be followed by more clashes.

The family of one of the three murdered Israeli teens has also issued a statement condemning the latest killing. Israeli police are still investigating the motives for the murder of Mohammed Abu Khdeir. The bodies of the three Jewish teens were found on Monday, two-and-a-half weeks after they
answers: Mohammed Abu Khudair was heading to morning prayers at 4am yesterday when neighbors saw him forced into a van in east Jerusalem, his father says. They called his cell phone but "my son wasn't answering," his mother adds, per the BBC. An hour later, the Palestinian teen was found dead in an apparent revenge killing, so burned beyond recognition that DNA samples were needed to confirm his identify, father Hussein Abu Khudair tells NBC News, adding, per Time, "The settlers killed my son, they kidnapped him and killed him." More developments: The teen's funeral, originally set for today, has been delayed as authorities perform an autopsy, his father says. Khudair adds he doesn't have faith in the Israeli police "because we're Arab" and says young Jews pulled a 9-year-old boy away from his mother after Mohammed's death. Though he was saved, "he was scratched," Khudair says. "They grabbed him by his neck." Another relative of Mohammed adds "the hatred has increased" instantly in the family's neighborhood. "I've never seen such racism, even in the first and second intifada," he tells the New York Times. "We are entering a very dark time." Meanwhile, police are investigating what could be a third kidnapping after a girl called police from northern Israel. "She said that she was abducted and then the line went dead," an Israeli spokesman tells the Times. "We're searching the area. Helicopters are trying to track. We'll see what's going on there." In response to mortar and rocket attacks from Gaza, "the Israeli Air Force attacked 15 terror sites in Gaza early Thursday," an Israel Defense Forces official notes. "The targets included weapons manufacturing sites as well as training facilities." Some 10 Palestinians were reportedly injured.

pred:
In Other Words, a feminist bookstore in Portland, Oregon, has severed ties with the popular TV show Portlandia, which for six seasons used the store as a filming location for the fictional bookstore Women and Women First. The decision to discontinue the relationship with Portlandia was made in response to a series of issues, including the show's portrayal of transgender individuals, lack of diversity, and the negative impact on the local community.

The bookstore's management claims that Portlandia left their space in a mess, mistreated their staff, forced neighboring businesses to close without warning, and the small fee they received did not cover the losses incurred during filming. The show's portrayal of transgender individuals, specifically a joke involving Fred Armisen in a dress, was criticized as trans-antagonistic, trans-misogynist, and offensive.

Furthermore, the lack of diversity on Portlandia, particularly the absence of Black characters, was noted as problematic, given that In Other Words is located in a historically Black neighborhood in Portland and has a strong connection with the Black Lives Matter movement. The show's portrayal of gentrification was also criticized for trivializing the issue of mass displacement in Portland.

The current management of In Other Words, including the board, staff, and volunteers, were not involved in the initial decision to allow Portlandia to film at the store. They stand by their decision to discontinue the relationship with the show and have expressed their support for the "Fuck Portlandia" sign that was placed in the store's window.

The bookstore is seeking donations and volunteers to continue serving as a hub for Portland's social justice community. They invite those interested in supporting their stance or volunteering to contact them at scheduling@inotherwords.org.
answers: Portland's In Other Words bookstore is well known to Portlandia fans as the fictional Women and Women First bookstore featured in sketches on the show—but it's safe to say ties have been severed between the bookstore and the show, considering a sign that appears on the bookstore's door reading, "Fuck Portlandia! Transmisogyny – Racism – Gentrification – Queer Antagonism – Devaluation of Feminist Discourse." The Willamette Week tried on Tuesday to get an explanation from the bookstore, and a representative at first offered an interview, but also asked (repeatedly) for the Week to post a link to an online fundraiser the bookstore is running. After the Week declined to guarantee a link would be posted (though one did, in fact, end up getting posted in the ensuing article), the bookstore took back its offer of an interview in no uncertain terms. "After some consideration and research we've decided to officially tell the Willamette Weekly to go fuck themselves," read a message from the rep. "Your paper has absolutely zero journalistic professionalism and you are scummy rape apologists. Thanks for the opportunity tho! Have a great night." Then, Wednesday, a blog post went up on the bookstore's website explaining the "Fuck Portlandia" sign. It was placed on the window, and the store's relationship with the show was formally discontinued, as "a direct response to a particular egregious filming of the show in our space which saw our store left a mess, our staff mistreated, our neighbors forced to close and lose business for a day without warning, and our repeated attempts to obtain accountability or resolution dismissed," the blog post reads. "It was also a direct response to a show which is in every way diametrically opposed to our politics and the vision of society we’re organizing to realize. A show which has had a net negative effect on our neighborhood and the city of Portland as a whole." There's a lot more where that came from, here.

pred:
In a series of investigations, the California State Auditor's Office (State Auditor) has uncovered several instances of improper governmental activities by state employees and agencies. Over a period of several years, these activities resulted in significant financial losses for the state.

One of the most egregious cases involved a DMV data operator who slept for three hours a day at her desk for three years, costing the state over $40,000. Despite complaints from colleagues and evidence of inaccurate work, the DMV failed to take disciplinary action. The employee continues to work for the state.

Another case involved two facilities operations employees at California State University, Fresno who engaged in time and attendance abuse by taking extended breaks, costing the state over $111,000 in salary payments for work not performed.

At Kern Valley State Prison, an employee misused state time by regularly leaving work early, costing the state nearly $9,000.

At the Department of Motor Vehicles, a key data operator misused over 2,200 hours of work time by sleeping on the job, costing the state over $40,000. The employee's doctor had informed the department that she was unable to perform the job requirements, but the department was reluctant to take further action due to suspected medical issues.

At a Southern California adult prison, a nursing director reassigned a licensed vocational nurse to a position for which she was overqualified, causing the state to waste over $30,000 in unnecessary salary payments and overtime.

The California Department of Corrections and Rehabilitation overpaid a staff services analyst nearly $3,000 due to a failure to follow proper procedures.

A high-ranking Cal Fire chief built an unauthorized structure on state property using on-duty staff, violating rental agreements and state law. The structure was demolished, and the assistant chief was suspended for 30 days.

The California State Auditor's Office conducted investigations into 1,481 cases of alleged improper governmental activities in the past year. The State Auditor's report also highlighted the DMV's long wait times, prompting California lawmakers to schedule an August hearing to address the issue.
answers: An employee responsible for logging changes in address and vehicle ownership at the California DMV slept at least three hours a day at her desk for nearly four years—and still has a job. The woman's 2,200 hours spent napping between February 2014 and December 2017 meant she completed less than half of her expected amount of work and cost the state more than $40,000, according to a worker misconduct report released Tuesday by the state's auditor. Per USA Today, the woman's doctor told the DMV that she was unable to perform her work duties, though a later doctor's note said the opposite. The employee continues to work for the state, per the Sacramento Bee.

pred:
In Cairo, Egypt, political tensions escalated on December 5 and continued into December 6 as opposition protesters and supporters of President Mohamed Mursi clashed outside the presidential palace. The Muslim Brotherhood, the political wing of the Islamist movement, called for the protests in response to what they described as "oppressive abuses" by opposition parties. The clashes resulted in injuries and casualties, with two Islamists reportedly hit by gunfire and a leftist group claiming that one of their members had an ear cut off.

Vice President Mahmoud Mekky proposed a potential solution to the crisis, suggesting that amendments to the disputed articles in the draft constitution could be agreed upon with the opposition. This proposed agreement would then be submitted to the next parliament, to be elected after a referendum on the constitution scheduled for December 15. Mekky emphasized the need for consensus and respect for the opposition's demands.

The opposition coalition, however, has urged Mursi to retract a decree he issued on November 22 that gave him wide powers and shielded his decisions from judicial review. They have also called for the referendum on the constitution to be postponed. The opposition has accused Mursi of creating a new autocracy and causing the worst crisis since he took office in June 2012.

The United States, concerned about the stability of Egypt, a state with a peace deal with Israel and to which it provides $1.3 billion in military aid annually, has called for dialogue. U.S. Secretary of State Hillary Clinton stated that the new constitution should respect the rights of all citizens.

The clashes between Islamists and opposition protesters extended to other cities, with offices of the Muslim Brotherhood's political party being torched in Ismailia and Suez. Despite the violence, Mursi has shown no signs of backing down, expressing confidence that the Islamists can win the referendum and subsequent parliamentary election.

The opposition, comprising liberals, leftists, Christians, ex-Mubarak followers, and others, has yet to generate a mass movement or a grassroots political base to challenge the Brotherhood. The army, which has traditionally been the muscle behind Egyptian presidents, has returned to barracks, having apparently lost its appetite to intervene in politics.

The
answers: Egyptian President Mohamed Morsi returned to the presidential palace today after fleeing yesterday when it was thronged by protesters, Reuters reports. Though 200 demonstrators camped out overnight, traffic was back to normal today and riot police had left the area. In yesterday's clashes, 35 protesters and 40 police officers were hurt. And things are looking to heat up again soon: The Muslim Brotherhood has called for a protest at the palace today against the "oppressive abuses" of the opposition, and the opposition in response called for leftist demonstrators to head back to the palace, leading to fears of violent clashes. Opposition protesters want Morsi to retract his expanded powers and stop a Dec. 15 vote on the new constitution hastily drafted by Islamists. Though they called yesterday's protest a "last warning" to the president, Reuters notes that they have little real chance of stopping the vote, which Morsi is confident will approve the constitution.

The Jamaican Bobsled Team is set to make its return to the Winter Olympics after a 12-year absence, competing in the two-man bobsled event at the 2014 Winter Olympics in Sochi, Russia. The team, piloted by Winston Watts, qualified for the competition without participating in any World Cup events, having accumulated enough points in lower-tier races in North America.

In preparation for their debut, a song titled "The Bobsled Song" has been released, composed by Sidney Mills and Jon Notar, and produced by Groove Guild. The song is designed to sync perfectly with the rhythms of the bobsled track, and fans are encouraged to download it from BobsledSong.com and play it during the team's first heat on Sunday, 11:15AM EST, 2/16.

The lyrics of the song follow the course of the 1,500-meter (4,921-foot) track, with its 17 turns and a vertical drop of 125.5 meters (410 feet). The chorus, "It's bobsled time," echoes throughout the song. The final part of the song goes, "Last turn, keep your head down/I see the finish line/Jamaica rock the whole town."

The Jamaican Tourist Board is promoting the song, and an eight-bit animated music video for the song is available on YouTube. The song's upbeat, reggae-inspired tune, combined with the team's improbable underdog status, has made it a popular choice among fans.

Despite being considered a long shot to win a medal, the Jamaican team's return to the Winter Olympics has generated significant interest and excitement. Their journey to the Calgary Games in 1988 was previously depicted in the film "Cool Runnings."

Reporters covering the Olympics in Sochi are providing updates on the happenings of the games. To stay informed, follow AP journalists on Twitter at http://apne.ws/1c3WMiu. For those interested, a collection of GIFs depicting the evolution of the Winter Olympics can be found at a separate link.

In anticipation of the team's run, fans are
answers: Jamaica's incredible bobsledding run to the Winter Olympics now has a theme song to go with it—named, appropriately, "The Bobsled Song," the AP reports. The upbeat tune by Sidney Mills and Jon Notard plays perfectly in sync with the team's 4,921-foot run in Sochi and wraps up with "Last turn, keep your head down/I see the finish line/Jamaica rock the whole town," reports Mashable. (See the 8-bit video here.) Considered a long shot to win a medal, the two-man team of Marvin Dixon and Winston Watts are aiming to recapture the thrill of the 1988 film Cool Runnings and ride the crowd-funding high that paid for country's first bobsledding Olympic appearance since 2002.

pred:
Two former Nazi SS guards, aged 93 and 92, have been indicted by German prosecutors for their roles as accessories to murder while serving at the Stutthof concentration camp during World War II. The camp, located near the Polish city of Gdansk, is estimated to have resulted in the deaths of approximately 65,000 prisoners, including Jews, Poles, and Soviet prisoners of war. The defendants, who have not been named, served as guards and watched over prisoners who were forced to work outside the camp.

The indictments were filed last week at the state court in Muenster but were only announced this week. Both men deny any knowledge of the killings at the camp. However, German prosecutors argue that the defendants were aware of the various killing methods used in the camp and willingly supported several hundreds of inmates' killings in their function as guards.

Judith Meisel, an 88-year-old Holocaust survivor from St. Louis Park, has been identified as a key witness in the case. She survived the Stutthof concentration camp and has provided crucial details about the camp's atrocities to German authorities. Meisel identified one of the defendants, Johann Rehbogen, as a teenage SS officer who taunted prisoners, including Meisel, as they undressed each morning.

German prosecutors have been pursuing cases against former Nazis since 2011, using new legal reasoning that allows the prosecution of former Nazis who can't be tied to specific killings but can be linked to the operation of concentration camps. The trial for Rehbogen and Harry Paul Fritz Schulz, the other defendant, is expected to commence next summer if they are deemed healthy enough.

Meisel's involvement in the case has brought back painful memories, including witnessing camp inmates killed by injections and being forced on a death march with her sister, who also escaped. Despite the emotional toll, Meisel welcomes the opportunity to seek justice for her mother and to continue sharing her story for the important lessons it teaches about tolerance and racism.
answers: Judith Meisel says that when she was a teenager in the Stutthof concentration camp in western Poland, other prisoners told her: "Don't let us die without you mentioning what happened to us." The 88-year-old Minnesota resident has not forgotten: Her testimony helped German authorities indict two former guards from the camp where 65,000 people, including Meisel's mother, died, the Minneapolis Star Tribune reports. She identified one former guard, 94-year-old Johann Rehbogen, as the young SS officer who would taunt female prisoners as they undressed. Prosecutors say the men can't be tied to specific murders, but their work as guards made the killings possible. Meisel—who escaped along with her sister when inmates were sent on a "death march" away from the camp in 1945—says she is willing to relive her horrific experiences to help prosecutors. "This process of seeking answers and finding justice for my mother gives new meaning to my life," she says. The two former guards have been charged as accessories to murder, the AP reports. They deny any knowledge of killings at the camp, where thousands were starved to death or froze. Prosecutors say prisoners were also gassed to death, shot, and killed with lethal injections. Authorities say Meisel and several other Stutthof survivors in the US could be called as witnesses if the former guards are deemed healthy enough to stand trial. (A pendant found at the Sobibor camp helped reunite a family.)

In the realm of politics and entertainment, two significant stories have emerged recently.

Firstly, a woman named Heather Lind, who worked on the historical television show "Turn," has accused former President George H.W. Bush of sexually assaulting her during a photo opportunity in 2014. Lind's allegations, which she detailed in an Instagram post that has since been deleted, claim that Bush touched her inappropriately and made a lewd comment while being photographed. Bush has since issued an apology, stating that his actions were intended as an "attempt at humor" and that he did not mean to offend Lind.

However, the accusations against Bush did not end there. Another actress, Jordana Grolnick, has come forward with similar claims, stating that Bush touched her inappropriately during a photo opportunity in 2016. Grolnick described the incident as happening during a production of "The Hunchback of Notre Dame" in Maine.

In response to these accusations, Bush has issued a second apology, acknowledging that his behavior may have been seen as inappropriate by some. He explained that, due to his age and being wheelchair-bound, his hand often falls on the lower waist of people during photos.

Meanwhile, a woman named Lind has used the opportunity to reflect on the power of individuals, regardless of their position, to enact positive change and serve as symbols of democracy. She emphasized that the use of power for harm, such as in the case of Bush's alleged actions, is a misuse of that power.

In the wake of these allegations, several of Lind's colleagues have come forward to support her, including co-star Kevin McNally and the author of the book "Washington's Spies," on which "Turn" is based. The official Turn account also tweeted in support of Lind, emphasizing that sexual assault is a serious issue that should not be politicized.

These incidents come at a time when the entertainment industry is grappling with a wave of sexual harassment allegations, following the Weinstein scandal. The support shown towards Lind by her colleagues underscores the growing movement to address and eradicate such behavior in the industry.
answers: Actress Heather Lind accused former President George HW Bush of sexual assault in a now-deleted Instagram post Tuesday, saying the former president "touched her from behind" during a photo-op in 2014. The Turn: Washington's Spies star said the inappropriate behavior occurred during a special screening before the AMC historical drama's debut, Deadline reports. "He touched me from behind from his wheelchair with his wife Barbara Bush by his side," Lind wrote. "He told me a dirty joke. And then, all the while being photographed, touched me again. Barbara rolled her eyes as if to say 'not again.'" Lind said a security guard told her she "shouldn't have stood next to him for the photo." Lind said that judging from comments from people around her, Bush had behaved the same way with "countless other women." "My fellow castmates and producers helped me that day and continue to support me," she wrote. Lind said she decided to come forward with her story after seeing a recent photo of the 93-year-old Bush with former President Obama. Bush issued an apology through a spokesman. "President Bush would never—under any circumstance—intentionally cause anyone distress, and he most sincerely apologizes if his attempt at humor offended Ms. Lind," the spokesman said in a statement to the New York Daily News.

pred:
In the North African region, two significant events are unfolding. Firstly, due to the ongoing civil war in Libya, approximately 30,000 Libyans have fled to Tunisia, seeking refuge from the violence. In a remarkable display of hospitality and solidarity, the inhabitants of Tataouine, Tunisia, a town with a population of 150,000, have opened their homes to these refugees. This generosity is particularly noteworthy given Tunisia's own economic challenges and previous waves of Libyan refugees this year. The United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees has praised the Tunisian government for keeping the borders open, allowing for the influx of refugees.

Secondly, the conflict in Libya has spilled over into Tunisia, with Libyan forces battling rebels on the Dehiba-Wazin border crossing. This incursion, although brief and seemingly apologized for by Libyan forces, has sparked outrage in Tunisia. The Tunisian authorities have demanded immediate measures to stop these violations, emphasizing the gravity of the situation. The fighting for the border post has been typical of the fluid and confused conflict that has been ongoing since mid-February.

In the Libyan city of Misrata, the plight of residents has worsened. Rebels accuse Gaddafi's forces of firing bigger rockets, causing greater destruction. Gaddafi denies these allegations, claiming that his forces are targeting Islamist militants and foreign-backed agitators. The rebels have called on NATO to intervene, stating that the air strikes are necessary to protect civilians. However, there is growing international criticism of NATO's involvement, with some arguing that the Western alliance is trying to overthrow the Libyan government by stretching the terms of a U.N. resolution.

In other developments, Libyan forces have taken control of a town in the remote southeastern desert, but rebels deny this claim. Meanwhile, in Tripoli, NATO jets have conducted air strikes, and the official Libyan news agency reported that civilian and military sites were hit, resulting in casualties. The exact targets of these attacks are unclear.
answers: Tunisia was not pleased today when a battle between Libya’s warring factions spilled across the border today, after Moammar Gadhafi’s forces attacked a rebel-held frontier crossing. The incursion was brief and limited, and Gadhafi’s forces even apologized locally, Reuters reports. But Tunisia’s foreign ministry still issued a statement expressing “extreme indignation” and demanding “measures to put an immediate stop to these violations.” But Tunisia has proven remarkably welcoming to Libyans who aren’t fighting. Some 30,000 refugees have fled there, and the vast majority of them have been welcomed into the homes of Tunisians, the New York Times reports. Only about 2,500 have had to settle in the relatively small refugee camp at the border. “It’s the first time I’ve seen such an impressive response,” says a spokesman for the UN’s High Commissioner for Refugees.

pred:
In the news, there are reports of Republican presidential candidate Rick Perry's unusual performance at an event in New Hampshire. A video of the event, which was posted on YouTube by an account named CharlieJohnson1986, shows Perry accepting a jug of maple syrup in a seemingly animated and energetic manner. The video, while not a full version of his speech, highlights some of the giddiest and strangest moments of a roughly 25-minute speech.

The video has sparked speculation about Perry's state during the speech, with Mother Jones suggesting that he might have been drunk, while the Huffington Post reports that the speech was unusually expressive. However, Perry's spokesman, Mark Miner, later stated that Perry was simply passionate about the issues he was discussing.

Mayor Ted Gatsas of Manchester, who was present at the event, described the speech as different. The Huffington Post reached out to Perry's spokesman for comment on Saturday, but received no response until Saturday night when Miner stated that Perry was passionate about the issues he was talking about.

The video has since gone viral, with many people sharing and commenting on Perry's animated performance. The video has also led to the creation of animated GIFs from the speech. answers: Was Rick Perry pie-eyed during a speech to a conservative group in New Hampshire on Friday? In a video that has since gone viral, the candidate adopted an exuberant, jokey style and pulled a lot of funny faces, leading some commentators to believe that the Texas governor was distinctly refreshed. "It was different," the mayor of Manchester told the Huffington Post after the speech. The speech shows that Perry is "passionate about the issues he talks about," a campaign spokeswoman says. "We're not saying that he's definitely drunk, we're just saying, watch the whole thing," muses Max Read at Gawker.

answers: A tourist boat packed with about 160 passengers capsized Sunday on a reservoir near the Colombian city of Medellin, leaving at least six people dead and 31 missing, officials said. Rescuers including firefighters and air force pilots in helicopters searched for survivors at the Guatape reservoir where El Almirante ferry sank. A flotilla of recreational boats and jet skis rushed to the scene, pulling people from the boat as it went down and avoiding an even deadlier tragedy, the AP reports. Dramatic videos circulating on social media show the party boat rocking back and forth as people crawled down from a fourth-floor roof as it began sinking into the water. "Those on the first and second floors sank immediately," a female survivor told Teleantioquia. "The boat was sinking and all we could do was scream and call for help." Survivors described hearing a loud explosion near the men's bathroom that knocked out power a few minutes after the boat began its cruise around the lake. It's unclear what caused the boat to sink, but survivors said that it appeared to be overloaded and nobody on board was wearing a life vest. After arriving at the scene, Colombian President Juan Manuel Santos said 122 people were either rescued or found their way to shore, but six had died and another 31 were missing, he told reporters.

Hay acknowledged her past tweets on Sunday, stating, "I admit that I have used language publicly in the past which I am not proud of and that there is no excuse for." The Miss Universe Organization, the parent company of Miss Teen USA, said in a statement that the language Hay used was unacceptable but that she will keep her crown. Karlie Hay has expressed remorse for her past language and stated that she has learned from her mistakes and is a better person as a result of her struggles. answers: Miss Teen USA 2016 was supposed to take a step in the direction of feminism and equal rights as the contest ditched the swimsuits for athletic wear. But in the wee hours following the event that crowned Miss Texas Karlie Hay, the 18-year-old high school senior took to Twitter to do damage control on, well, previous comments on social media. Accused of repeatedly using racial slurs, people began to take screenshots and call her out on it, reports the Houston Chronicle. Hay, her school's varsity cheer captain and yearbook editor, apologized on Twitter at 2am Sunday: "I admit that I have used language publicly in the past which I am not proud of and that there is no excuse for. Through hard work, education and thanks in large part to the sisterhood that I have come to know through pageants, I am proud to say that I am today a better person." Former Miss Teen USA Kamie Crawford issued her own message on Twitter: "If you win any pageant—first things first. Clean up your page. Because if you're under 21, you shouldn't be drinking and if you're white, the N-word ain't your word." The Miss Universe Organization, parent company of Miss Teen USA, tells ABC News that while Hay's language was "unacceptable at any age," she will keep her crown because she "learned many lessons through those personal struggles that reshaped her life and values." I'm not gonna write a think-piece on a damn pageant."

The news presents two interconnected stories about Julius Rosenwald, a Jewish American businessman and philanthropist of the early 20th century. Peter Ascoli's biography, "Julius Rosenwald: A Life in Perspective," reveals Rosenwald's transformation of Sears, Roebuck into the country's most significant retailer, his philanthropic activities, and his lifelong devotion to community service. Notably, Rosenwald funded the construction of more than 5,300 schools in the American South, many of which still bear his name.

However, the charitable fund he created during World War I ceased to exist in 1948 at his expressed wish. Rosenwald's philanthropy had a profound impact on African-American culture and education, helping to change the course of education for thousands of children in the rural South. He also supported the careers of prominent African-American artists, including Langston Hughes, Marion Anderson, and Jacob Lawrence.

In a contemporary context, Alex Bethea, a vice principal at an elementary school in New Jersey, learned that his school was named after Julius Rosenwald. This revelation came at a screening of the documentary "Rosenwald" at the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People (NAACP) convention in Philadelphia. The film, produced by Aviva Kempner, celebrates the affinity between African-Americans and Jews and speaks to the powerful Jewish tradition of tikkun olam, or repairing the world.

The documentary features interviews with notable African-Americans like Maya Angelou, U.S. Rep. John Lewis (D-Ga.), and Julian Bond, who attended Rosenwald schools as children. They share their experiences and express gratitude for Rosenwald's commitment to ensuring that black American children received a quality education. The film is set to be released in theaters in mid-August.

In summary, the news highlights the inspiring story of Julius Rosenwald, a Jewish philanthropist who, through his business acumen and charitable endeavors, made a significant impact on American education and African-American culture. His legacy continues to resonate, as evidenced by the ongoing appreciation for his contributions from those who benefited from his schools. The recent documentary "Rosenwald" serves as a testament to his life and work, and it aims to
answers: Julius Rosenwald is well known as the 20th-century American businessman who co-founded what we now call Sears. But a new documentary by Aviva Kempner explores Rosenwald's lesser-known role as a Jewish philanthropist who brought education to thousands of African-American children at a time when most had no schools to attend, reports the Root. "It's a wonderful story of cooperation between this philanthropist who did not have to care about black people, but who did, and who expended his considerable wealth in ensuring that they got their fair shake in America," civil rights leader Julian Bond explains in Rosenwald, out next month. It tells of Rosenwald's rise from the son of a peddler to a clothing manufacturing apprentice to CEO of the largest US retailer, Sears, Roebuck & Co., in 1908, reports the Times of Israel. It was around that time he began to see similarities between the treatment of blacks in America and pogroms against European Jews. When his rabbi became an NAACP leader, Rosenwald sponsored meetings. Soon after, he donated $25,000 to Alabama's Tuskegee University, led by Booker T. Washington, whose writings on racial equality and education had piqued his interest. Washington suggested the money go toward building six schools for black children, but Rosenwald contributed just a third of the funds and pushed the black and white communities to raise the rest. He went on to give $62 million to various causes, including the Rosenwald Fund, which created 5,300 schools in the South, attended by prominent African-Americans like Maya Angelou, George Wolfe, and Eugene Robinson. It "was the single-most important funding agency for African-American culture in the 20th century," poet Rita Dove says. More than 80 years after his death, Rosenwald still inspires. "Not all of us can be Julius Rosenwald," says Kempner, but "we can all do something."

In the United Kingdom, a brutal attack took place on May 22, 2013, in Woolwich, south-east London, where a soldier named Lee Rigby, aged 25, was murdered by two suspects identified as Michael Adebolajo, 28, and Michael Oluwatobi Adebowale, 22. The attackers were known to the MI5 intelligence services for their extremist views, but the government defended the security services against criticism that they missed signs that could have prevented the murder.

The attack was captured on video, showing the suspects beheading Rigby and then setting up an ambush for the first police officers to arrive at the scene. The police responded quickly, shooting and arresting the two suspects, who were taken to separate London hospitals in stable conditions.

The investigation continued with two more arrests on Thursday, a 29-year-old man and a 29-year-old woman, on suspicion of conspiring to murder. The initial suspects, Adebolajo and Adebowale, had previously surfaced in probes of Islamist extremists.

The attack shocked Londoners and revived the debate on how to confront extremism in the UK. The Muslim Council of Britain condemned the attack, calling it a "barbaric act that has no basis in Islam." The Prime Minister, David Cameron, met with top security and government officials to discuss the investigation, stating that the attack would only bring the country together and make them stronger.

In a separate news, Alexa Internet has been donating their crawl data to the Internet Archive since 1996, which is added to the Wayback Machine after an embargo period. This data is used to preserve the history of the internet.
answers: The plot to kill a soldier in the streets of London may have gone deeper than the two men who hacked Lee Rigby to death. Police yesterday arrested two more people, a man and a woman, both 29, as suspected conspirators in the attack, the Wall Street Journal reports. They also searched the homes of six people—including, reportedly, suspect Michael Adebolajo's father's home. Neither these two conspirators nor the wounded alleged killers have been charged yet. Other developments include: Police also haven't identified any of the suspects, but Adebolajo's name was widely reported yesterday, and today the Telegraph has identified the other alleged knife-man as the confusingly similarly named Michael Adebowale, 22. Neighbors identified Adebowale after police armed with submachine guns raided his flat yesterday, emerging with two children, a baby, and two large envelopes. Adebowale was apparently known for distributing radical Islamist leaflets, and his girlfriend had recently converted to Islam. "When you walked past, you would hear them singing Muslim songs," one neighbor says, adding that she "saw the man who was in the video go inside the house. I think he was a boyfriend." Rigby, "was due to come up this weekend," his wife tells the Guardian. "You don't expect it to happen when he's in the UK. You think they're safe." The Daily Mirror has uncovered video that purports to show the two suspects rushing at police and getting shot. There's also been a great deal of hand-wringing over MI5's failure to identify the stabbers ahead of time. David Cameron is calling for an investigation to determine "what went wrong" at the intelligence agency. Communities Secretary Eric Pickles has promised just such an investigation. But he also defended the agency to the BBC, saying it was "difficult in a free society to be able to control everyone."

pred:
The news articles discuss the need for encouraging girls to become leaders in the workforce, particularly in corporate leadership positions, as the 20-year anniversary of the Ms. Foundation's Take Our Daughters to Work Day has passed. The focus is shifting from demystifying the workplace for girls to promoting leadership roles, as it is observed that women are underrepresented in top corporate positions.

The articles suggest that companies should introduce girls to female role models, provide clear understanding of leadership roles, and actively identify and groom female talent. The idea is to bridge the gap between the lack of women in leadership positions, which is seen as a significant issue for the competitiveness of companies and the ideals of fairness and social equality.

Jennifer Allyn, a managing director at PricewaterhouseCoopers LLP, and Meg Whitman, CEO of Hewlett Packard, are among those advocating for a new initiative, Take Our Daughters to the C-Suite Day, to bring girls inside the offices of corporate chiefs. The aim is to inspire girls to become leaders and provide them with a clearer picture of what leadership entails on a daily basis.

The articles also highlight the importance of sponsorship in corporate environments, where sponsors spend their political capital on behalf of their protégés, providing opportunities instead of just advice. Companies with formal sponsorship initiatives are seen as leaders in diversity.

The articles cite examples such as Princeton University's proactive efforts to encourage female students to apply for academic prizes and hold visible leadership roles, which led to a significant increase in the number of female Rhodes Scholars.

In conclusion, the news articles emphasize the need for a shift in focus from simply exposing girls to the workplace to actively encouraging and supporting them to become leaders. This is seen as crucial for achieving gender equality, improving competitiveness, and fostering a fair and equal society.
answers: Today is the 20th anniversary of Take Our Daughters to Work Day, and Jennifer Allyn at the Christian Science Monitor says it's time to declare mission accomplished and refocus on a bigger goal. Two decades ago, it was enough to get young girls in the workplace and "demystify" the whole concept of women getting a job. Now it's time to introduce girls to the executive suites, to give them role models of women as decision-makers. Girls still tend not to see themselves getting leadership positions as adults, and that's because they don't get to see enough real-life examples. "Simply showing our daughters what an office looks like is no longer enough," writes Allen. "Real breakthroughs will come when we bring girls inside the halls of power. We need to take our daughters into the C-Suite now so they can lead in the future." Click to read her entire column.
